Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12: Global Change in a Local Context: Partners in Discovery of the Columbia River Watershed

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
GRADUATE TEACHING FELLOWS IN K-12 EDUCATION
ABSTRACT

PROPOSAL #: 0742561
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Gretchen Rollwagen-Bollens
INSTITUTION: Washington State University
TITLE: Global Change in a Local Context: Partners in Discovery of the Columbia River Watershed


The Partners in Discovery GK-12 project brings Washington State University Vancouver (WSUV) science graduate students and faculty together with Clark County, Washington, science teachers in a collaborative partnership. The central theme of this GK-12 project is ?Global Change in a Local Context,? with the Columbia River Watershed as the unifying environmental feature around which students connect science concepts from their classrooms to their own ?backyard.? Clark County is located on the southwest border of Washington State, along a 100-mile stretch of the lower Columbia River. The Columbia River Watershed, extending from the high Cascade glaciers to the estuary and river mouth, encompasses the entire county and is the defining feature of this region ? environmentally, economically and culturally. Clark County, with nearly 400,000 residents, is the fastest-growing county in Washington, and is experiencing dramatic changes in population, housing construction, land use, etc., that are directly impacting the watershed. Thus the watershed and the Global/Local theme provide a compelling and relevant context within which to explore science disciplinary content (Earth, Life and Physical Sciences) through inquiry, and in particular how change in nature is manifested in a local system and how those changes affect students as individuals and communities.

The Partners in Discovery GK-12 project is structured around year-long one-on-one partnerships between WSUV graduate student Fellows and grades 6th ? 9th science Teachers in four Clark County school districts. Fellows and Teachers will engage students in authentic scientific inquiry focused on the nature and impacts of change in the Columbia River Watershed. The Fellow-Teacher partnerships will utilize each district?s existing curriculum and revise or augment their science ?kits? by identifying questions and inquiry activities that link instructional modules to state and national science standards, and to the complementary expertise of WSUV research faculty and graduate students working in the Watershed. The program will support 6 to 10 Fellows-teacher partnerships per year for a total of five years.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Partners in Discovery of the Columbia River Watershed” GK-12 project brought Washington State University Vancouver (WSUV) environmental science graduate students and faculty together with Clark County, Washington science teachers in a collaborative partnership.  The central theme of this GK-12 project was “Global Change in a Local Context,” with the Columbia River Watershed as the unifying environmental and cultural feature around which students connected science concepts from their classrooms to their own “backyard.”

The primary focus of our project was the one-on-one partnership between a WSUV environmental science graduate student Fellow and a 6th – 9th grade science teacher.  In this GK-12 project, we encouraged and provided opportunities for GK-12 Fellows and science teachers to participate in constructive dialogue and collaboration to deeply understand, build upon, and expand existing, science curricula with inquiry-based activities and lessons specifically related to the Columbia River Watershed and aligned with both Washington state and national science standards.  This collaboration between the Fellow and teacher primarily occurred in the teacher’s classroom as the partners jointly developed and led these activities, and worked together to engage students in the teacher’s curriculum.  The Partners in Discovery project also provided participants with meaningful and relevant professional development led by WSUV science and education faculty, through a bi-weekly pedagogy seminar series for Fellows, two full-day and four late afternoon professional development workshops for all participants during the academic year.

Our overall project goals were to:

  1. Improve graduate student Fellows’ abilities to teach science through inquiry, to use and apply research in the classroom, and to communicate science to non-scientists; also to improve Fellows’ appreciation for and commitment to K-12 outreach.
  2. Improve Teachers’ abilities to teach science through inquiry and to use and apply research in the classroom; also to improve Teachers’ science content knowledge.
  3. Enrich Clark County 6th – 9th grade students’ science education and build their enthusiasm for science.
  4. Strengthen scientist-teacher partnerships between WSUV and Clark County schools.
  5. Integrate the GK-12 partnership model into all WSUV Science graduate programs.

At the end of our 5-year GK-12 project, our teacher participants reported that the Fellows’ ability to teach to middle school students improved and that the Fellows had a better understanding of how middle school students learn. Most teachers reported that the fellows improved their communication skills and improved their ability to engage the class by using hands-on activities or visuals.  Moreover, all teachers and Fellows reported that the Fellows gained an appreciation for the challenges teachers face, and better understood the constraints teachers work within when using a particular curriculum and trying to adapt their teaching to meet changing standards.  Most importantly, all of the Fellows interviewed were eager to collaborate with K–12 educators in some future capacity.
